awd_titl_txt: Data Collection and Analysis from the ARIANNA Sub-array Stations
awd_abstract_narration:
The quest to detect and measure ultra-high-energy neutrinos (>100 petaelectronvolts, PeV) is at the forefront of particle astrophysics and has been going on for many years. Detectors that exploit photomultipliers, like the IceCube Neutrino Observatory at South Pole, have made significant progress detecting neutrinos up to 1-2 PeV, but to instrument realistic larger target mass volumes, one needs to turn to techniques like the radio detection of high-energy neutrinos in media where radio waves can easily propagate ? like an ice sheet or shelf. The neutrinos being searched for can bring essential information about their origins, where and how they were made, and thereby shed light on the origins of ultra-high-energy cosmic rays. The nature of cosmic accelerators is one of the key questions of modern high-energy astrophysics.

Antarctic Ross Ice-Shelf ANtenna Neutrino Array (ARIANNA) is one of the proposed detectors for ultra-high energy astrophysical neutrinos, which is designed to measure coherent radio Cherenkov emissions from particle showers produced by neutrino interactions within ice. ARIANNA can be built on the Ross Ice Shelf just off the coast of Antarctica (~100-km south from McMurdo Station), eventually covering about 1000 square-km in surface area. There, the ice-water interface below the ~600-m thick shelf reflects radio waves, giving ARIANNA sensitivity to downward going neutrinos and improving its sensitivity to horizontally incident neutrinos.

The primary goal of this award is to complete the deployment of the remaining four stations for the pilot 7-station Hexagonal Radio Array (HRA, approximately 2-km distance between sides) that can serve as a "building block" for a much larger ARIANNA project, ultimately consisting of ~960 stations. Upon completing the HRA deployment, the focus will be on analysis tasks: carefully examining the data collected by the HRA stations, characterizing the sources and properties of non-thermal contributions, and monitoring the robustness of the HRA stations in its year-round operation. These stations operate autonomously, using solar power for about 7 months and going to sleep for austral winter months. 

Anticipated broader impacts from this project include training graduate students, furthering international scientific collaboration and cooperation in Antarctica, and providing data that will be of significant importance and use by the neutrino astrophysics community.

por.por_cntn:
The origin of Ultra-High-Energy (UHE) cosmic rays remains one of the great mysteries of astrophysics. Cosmogenic neutrinos created by cosmic ray collisions in deep space come hurtling towards the Earth at energies between 1016-1020eV, well above the energy scale of the most powerful manmade accelerator - Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, Switzerland. In 2013, high energy neutrino astronomy began when the IceCube neutrino detector at the South Pole announced that it had discovered 28 of neutrinos, though at energies too small to be cosmogenic neutrinos. Researchers do not know what is creating the neutrinos seen by IceCube.

This broad goal of this project is to open the extreme energy window of neutrino astronomy by constructing an array of 1296 ARIANNA stations. This state-of-the-art neutrino telescope exploits the revolutionary Askaryan radio technique to target the extreme energy spectrum, defined here to be 1016-1020 eV. 

ARIANNA will improve source identification because it can measure the direction of extreme energy neutrinos with 3 degree precision compared to 10-15 degrees for most neutrinos detected by IceCube. Conversely, IceCube can measure the events with better energy resolution. Since both detectors view almost the same sky at extreme energies, there is even greater power when results are combined. For example, the observation of a rare, explosive source by two independent telescopes with different systematic uncertainties is almost a scientific necessity for such an important discovery.

Known astrophysical processes and events, such as Fermi acceleration of protons in a magnetic field, break down at the extreme energy of most powerful cosmic rays, thus another source for their generation must be found. Neutrinos - uncharged, nearly masses subatomic particles - interact with other matter through only the weakest of nature’s forces, so offer a unique tool for investigating these cosmological processes. On account of this, however, they are among the most difficult particles in the universe to detect, requiring new technologies deployed over an area the size of the city of Los Angeles.

In October 2015, for the second time in 13 years, the Nobel committee cited pioneering science arising from the use of neutrino telescopes. We believe that the development of the next generation of neutrino telescopes will continue to deliver Nobel-worthy results of fundamental importance. ARIANNA will allow researchers to understand and perhaps visualize the sources of extragalactic cosmic rays by the detection of cosmogenic or hard-spectra neutrinos. Moreover, ARIANNA is uniquely capable of measuring the mysterious IceCube events if they extend to even higher energies, allowing researchers to unravel their origins. ARIANNA was designed to pursue the unknown in the neutrino sky at extreme energies. 

NSF-funded a 7-station pilot program of ARIANNA, called the Hexagonal Radio Array.  It has been operating successfully since December 2014, and has demonstrated superior performance to competing concepts such as the Askaryan Radio Array. This advantage stems from ARIANNA’s unique location and design. Positioned on the Ross Ice Shelf, ARIANNA operates in an environment virtually free of all anthropogenic noise, allowing it to probe deeper with vastly fewer spurious events.  ARIANNA’s technology is far less costly than IceCube, so it is expandable, and unlike the fossil-fuel-dependent drilling and power sources of other concepts, it is a “green” surface array powered solely by the sun.  

Given the success of ARIANNA pilot program, the collaboration plans to propose to construct and deploy 1296 detector stations, each with 8 log-periodic dipole antennas, in a rectangular grid on the surface of the Ross Ice Shelf. The stations will communicate with the Iridium satellite network. The construction of the ARIANNA array will require 3 to 4 years after the start of funding.
